summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from July 22, 2020, covering a wide range of national news topics. It includes a section on criminal investigations mentioning that a federal judge is considering releasing Ghislaine Maxwell's sealed testimony from a 2015 defamation lawsuit, and that Maxwell's lawyers requested a gag order in her criminal case. The briefing also covers other FBI investigations, political news, and international affairs.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in the criminal investigations section; facing charges of trafficking girls for Jeffrey Epstein; her lawyers requested a gag order to limit pretrial publicity.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as Maxwell's former boyfriend; Maxwell is accused of trafficking girls for him.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Epstein accuser who filed a 2015 defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell, which is the source of sealed records a judge is considering releasing.

persons.name: Loretta Preska
persons.context: US District Judge in New York who scheduled a conference to discuss unsealing documents from the 2015 Giuffre v. Maxwell defamation lawsuit.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: US District Judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal case; her lawyers filed a request for a gag order with this judge.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: A lawyer for Ghislaine Maxwell who filed a letter requesting a gag order in her criminal case.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York; cited by Maxwell's lawyer as having made public comments after Maxwell's arrest.

persons.name: William Sweeney
persons.context: Head of the New York FBI office; cited by Maxwell's lawyer for comments made at a news conference calling Maxwell a 'villain'.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in various news sections; was asked about Ghislaine Maxwell and said he hadn't followed her case closely and wished her well.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as the former girlfriend and alleged co-conspirator of Jeffrey Epstein, accused of trafficking girls for him.
Giuffre is an Epstein accuser who sued Maxwell for defamation in 2015, leading to the sealed records a judge may release.
Pagliuca is a lawyer representing Ghislaine Maxwell in her criminal case, as evidenced by his filing of a gag order request.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested in Bradford, New Hampshire, on sex trafficking charges related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Gag Order Request in Maxwell Case
events.description: Lawyers for Ghislaine Maxwell filed a request for a gag order on prosecutors, FBI agents, and lawyers to limit prejudicial pretrial publicity.

events.title: Scheduled Conference on Unsealing Maxwell Records
events.description: Judge Loretta Preska scheduled a conference to discuss unsealing documents from the 2015 Virginia Giuffre v. Ghislaine Maxwell defamation lawsuit.

events.title: Giuffre v. Maxwell Defamation Lawsuit
events.description: Virginia Giuffre sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, claiming Maxwell called her a liar regarding allegations against Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: A federal judge is considering unsealing records from a 2015 defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell filed by Epstein accuser Virginia Giuffre.
Ghislaine Maxwell's lawyers requested a gag order in her criminal case, citing public comments by the Acting U.S. Attorney and the head of the New York FBI office.
President Trump commented on the Maxwell case, stating he had not followed it closely, had met her numerous times, and wished her well.
The document is a broad news briefing covering many topics; the Epstein/Maxwell references are a small part of the criminal investigations section.
